@rebelempiricist I increasingly think that the "prompt engineering" era will in fact be quite short, and models will be able to give you what you want no matter how clumsy your prompting is within a generation or two (so, 2-4 years max)

@Samhanknr @tszzl >an individual human lifetime is more analogous to few shot prompt engineering of the pretrained human foundation than learning language or reasoning from scratch

This does imply that and is very obviously false.

That's how we should frame today's conversation around AI and people's reticence to get back to neuro.

Benchmarking? Trial and error? Prompt engineering? Scale is all you need?

Given what I said above, it's all just a fool's errand.

@JayMacjoy @nbashaw @lexdotpage No. Not even redoing Lex's generations would yield the same results. What I mean by being the same is that most are built on top of GPT-3 in pretty much the same way (prompt engineering and/or fine-tuning)

Explore/Adapt:

Instead of collecting a large labelled dataset and training a model, you explore your use case through prompt engineering, you may also consider fine tuning the model to adapt it to your situation. Opportunities for tooling in prompt engineering & fine tuning.

@mattshumer_ Agree with you insofar as "prompt engineering" = futzing around with wording/variations/settings, but I do think that there will still be important workflows of "prompt engineering" to explore different approaches for a given use case and tinkering with chaining compositions

@rasbt Prompt engineering should have its own category since it‚Äôs especially unique to LLM and language tasks.

@rasbt @ankrgyl This is where I get bothered. Allowing ‚Äúprompt engineering‚Äù techniques to make it into high-rated academic literature seems‚Ä¶ off, somehow?

It feels like it needs a different conference. Although impactful, it doesn‚Äôt fit with ‚Äútrue‚Äù ML work.

@rasbt The hype around prompt engineering is in making a tool useful for you. AI for many is a new productivity or creativity tool that was previously out of reach or not good enough for their needs ‚Äî prompt engineering is the way it reaches them.

Also porn.
@lathropa How different do the generated images have to be? Can we use prompt engineering to have a machine generate a nearly identical image, now royalty-free?

@rasbt That paper focuses more on distillation of latent knowledge that already is in the model.  Other work on prompt engineering focuses on adding info in the prompt and / or few-shot learning using an existing model and a small amount of extra data.

@casio_juarez @rasbt I might take this a step further: they‚Äôre specialized software, and they need a better UX than ‚Äúspend $10M to retrain the model‚Äù. 

They‚Äôre a major advance/expansion of user-facing ML, and prompt engineering is just another user-facing feature.

@rasbt @ankrgyl Copilot is "prompt engineering" and programming. There are things that you can do with prompt conditioning/templates by example that you simply cannot train, at least not without an unreasonable amount of time and effort.

@rasbt I'm sure people said that about compilers, frameworks and many other things. The cool thing about prompt engineering is that you can get something working in a matter of hours (or less), without gathering any data. That's important to get business buy-in for new use cases.
@rasbt Hence, why I don't think prompt engineering is a bad direction.

(9/10) A big question is how improvements in GPT-N or other model-N eliminate this need. Will widespread adoption be possible with today‚Äôs version of unstructured prompt engineering and how soon will model advancements overcome the quality issue? (Shoutout to @RachelWineNerd)

(6/10) With all the advancement in foundational models, we need prompt-engineering-as-a-service, or even fine-tuning-as-a-service, which provide interactive and structured mediums that translate the user‚Äôs intended objective into model inputs to enable highly effective content.

(4/10) There is significant nuance and varying advice on how to prompt an AI system, from ‚Äúexplain it like I‚Äôm in 2nd grade‚Äù to automated guided searching scripts.  Highly recommend @mihail_eric's guide to read a summary of the research: https://t.co/AbcpIh47lK

(2/10) As a data scientist, it is satisfying to see real people using AI products for ad creation, emails, recipes. Beyond the initial magic, they are struggling to leverage the value in real life workflows. Here‚Äôs why I think the next opportunity abstracts prompt engineering:

üßµ(1/10) Using text directly as an interface for generative AI doesn‚Äôt inherently mean humans can suddenly efficiently interface with AI‚Ä¶ There is a still a gap in enabling humans to meaningful communicate the outputs they desire, aka prompt engineering. And to do so iteratively

Prompt engineering isn‚Äôt a UI that‚Äôs designed by another human to be good & usable. It‚Äôs just a byproduct of the way that ML models are trained. Not to say that you can‚Äôt get good results with it, but it‚Äôs not user-friendly.

Maybe it‚Äôs that ‚Äòprompt engineering‚Äô is having to reverse engineer the patterns - both intuitive & unintuitive - that an algorithm has abstracted from an arbitrary set of data and it‚Äôs a huge faff ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è https://t.co/MoyDa0smmf

4) Reynolds and McDonell provide a neat formalism for how to think about prompt formulation. Few-shot "learning" is likely a misnomer. There's no learning happening, just locating previously learned tasks. That's the job of good prompt engineering. https://t.co/rxcm4bF9nB
